author: Amanda Falcone

text: Whoops, I meant ‚Äúheroin addictions*‚Äù in the first sentence, not ‚Äúheroin addicts‚Äù. And if anyone doesn‚Äôt believe me, I‚Äôm in recovery myself from opiates now, and over the 7.5 years I was addicted to heroin, I was constantly told time + time again (by drug dealers + trappers, of all people, lol) that they all enjoyed serving me because I look like the complete opposite of what the media portrays a heroin addict to be. You‚Äôd think by now, with this epidemic, we‚Äôd all chill with the ignorant stereotypes ‚Äî heroin addicts are not just dirty, smelly scumbags who root thru trash cans for food or unlocked cars for change. Heroin addicts come in all shapes + sizes; they all look juuust like you + I. Addiction doesn‚Äôt discriminate; we all need to chill // end the stigma. It is entirely possible to look like the most clean-cut person alive, wearing designer clothing w| hair + nails done, yet could still be one of the most vicious, scum addicts you‚Äôve ever met. If I learned one thing while getting high, it‚Äôs that the people you *LEAST* expect are usually the ones who have fallen victim to it. I‚Äôve been told by drug dealers that they‚Äôve seen all walks of life: Teachers, doctors, cops, union workers, retail workers, fast food workers, etc. ... Doesn‚Äôt matter who you are ‚Äî if you‚Äôre not educated on the subject + decide to ‚Äú*try*‚Äù opiates, there‚Äôs a good chance you‚Äôll get addicted, especially depending on your mental health. (If you have any undiagnosed mental issues, especially bipolar or bipolar II, you‚Äôre obviously going to be much more prone to developing an addiction).Ôªø
